I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help strengthen the 
institutional and technical capacity for progressing gender equality outcomes in Pacific developing 
member countries (DMCs), particularly in the context of response and recovery from the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19). It will support Pacific DMCs to (i) identify gender mainstreaming opportunities 
and innovative and transformative gender projects and programs; (ii) strengthen DMC capacity to 
implement  and  monitor  gender  equality  actions;  and  (iii)  strengthen  gender  partnerships  and 
knowledge among Pacific DMCs. The outcomes are directly linked to the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) Strategy 2030 (specifically operational priority 2 of accelerating progress in gender equality) 
and Sustainable Development Goal 5 (achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls).1 
 
2.  The TA builds on previous ADB support for gender equality in the Pacific, in 2010 and 2016.2 
The earlier TA projects focused on strengthening the capacity of selected Pacific countries to use 
and produce gender statistics and develop regional and country-specific gender assessments in Fiji, 
Kiribati, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, and Tonga. The resulting data as well as 
previous capacity building will inform the outputs to be produced through this TA. 
 
3.  The TA is included in the current Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan3 and will support 
the implementation of the Gender Equality Operational Plan 2019–2024.4 It is also included as part 
of ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Gender inequality and gender gaps. Empowering women is vital to achieving inclusive, 
resilient, and sustainable development in the Pacific. Despite the progress made by many Pacific 
DMCs in advancing gender equality, a significant proportion of women and girls still face poverty, 
inequality, and exclusion. Customary norms and traditional beliefs on gender roles and the limited 
implementation of gender policies and legislation have limited women’s and girls’ access to essential 
services and resources. A significant and persistent gap between men’s and women’s participation 
in economic activity and labor markets is still evident across the region, where women are unable to 
access finance and credit and continue to work in low-paid jobs or in informal and vulnerable 
employment. Data show that in 2017, more than half of the people in vulnerable employment were 
women.6 Women’s  participation  in  decision-making  (both  formal  and  informal)  has  been  a 
longstanding  challenge.  While  there  are  good  examples  of  women’s  participation  in  senior 
management positions in both the public and private sphere—e.g., in the Cook Islands and Samoa, 
where their share exceeds 45%—Pacific women’s representation in decision-making positions is 
generally among the lowest in the world. As of April 2020, only 8.8% of parliamentarians in the Pacific 
were women (compared with a global average of 23.4%).7

2 
 
5.  Violence against women and girls. The Pacific has some of the highest rates of violence 
against women and girls (VAWG) in the world. 8 In various Pacific countries, more than 60% of 
women have reported experiencing violence from intimate partners in their lifetime, and more than 
30% of women report being sexually abused before the age of 15.9 The Pacific Partnership to End 
Violence Against Women and Girls (Pacific Partnership), was launched in 2018 and is funded by the 
European Union, the governments of Australia and New Zealand, and the United Nations Entity for 
Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women, known as UN Women; and implemented by the 
Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC), Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat, and UN Women. It 
brings together governments, civil society organizations, and other partners to promote gender 
equality, prevent VAWG, and increase access to quality response services. However, the prevention 
of VAWG is a new area of work globally, and the focus on VAWG prevention in the Pacific is limited. 
While Pacific research studies have contributed to greater knowledge of the prevalence and drivers 
of violence, practice-based lessons from locally led prevention efforts are not widely available or 
accessible. 
 
6.  Impact  of  COVID-19.  Measures  taken  to  prevent  the  transmission  of  COVID-19  are 
exacerbating many of the gender inequalities in Pacific DMCs and disproportionately affect women 
and girls. Women are at increased risk of infection, gender-based violence (GBV), job losses, and 
vulnerable work. This is coupled with limited social protection and less access to formal safety nets, 
less access to finance, increased burden of unpaid care work, loss of livelihoods, and less access 
to sexual and reproductive health services. 
 
7.  Border and travel restrictions are slowing tourism and remittances—both key income streams 
for women in Pacific DMCs. Non-pharmaceutical interventions such as lockdowns, movement 
restrictions, closure of shops, and prohibition of roadside vendors have a significant impact on 
women’s income. Existing gender pay gaps in paid employment and women’s overrepresentation in 
informal and vulnerable employment put women at increased risk of poverty and food insecurity as 
a result of COVID-19. The latest available data from 2017 show that women accounted for 53.6% of 
total employment in services and that most women-owned enterprises in the Pacific are tied to 
services, notably in wholesale and retail, and the hospitality and tourism industries—areas that are 
disproportionately  affected  by  COVID-19  (footnote  5).  In  general,  official  social  protection 
mechanisms are scarce across the Pacific (with the exception of social insurance and provident 
funds that mainly target formal employees in the public sector10), and social protection schemes that 
target women are even scarcer.  
 
8.  In addition to the economic impacts, COVID-19 also exacerbates the already large care duty 
of women (e.g., tending to children who are not at school, homeschooling children who are unable 
to attend regular classes, caring for sick family members with limited access to hospital care). In 
addition, VAWG (particularly sexual exploitation and intimate partner violence) is likely to increase 
because of movement restrictions and growing economic and health pressures. In Fiji, for example, 
domestic violence complaints to GBV support services (e.g., GBV hotlines) more than doubled in 
March and April 2020.11  
 
9.  ADB  Strategy  2030.  ADB  has  the  opportunity  to  support  ambitious  gender  equality 
outcomes  in  Pacific  DMCs  through  ADB  Strategy  2030  (footnote  1),  which  recognizes  the 
 
8  Gender-based violence (GBV) and VAWG are used interchangeably throughout the paper because most gender-based 
violence is perpetrated by men against women. VAWG is defined as "any act of gender-based violence that results in, 
or is likely to result in, physical, sexual or mental harm or suffering to women, including threats of such acts, coercion or 
arbitrary deprivation of liberty, whether occurring in public or in private life." (United Nations General Assembly, 1993). 
9  United Nations Population Fund. kNOwVAWdata: Measuring prevalence of violence against women in Asia-Pacific 
(accessed 22 June 2020). 
10  ADB. 2019. The Social Protection Indicator for the Pacific: Assessing Progress. Manila.   
11  UN Women. 2020. Across the Pacific, crisis centres respond to COVID-19 amid natural disasters. 10 June.

3 
 
challenging context for women and girls across Asia and the Pacific and highlights “accelerating 
progress in gender equality” as one of the seven operational priorities for achieving a prosperous, 
inclusive, resilient, and sustainable Asia and the Pacific. The ADB corporate results framework 
commits to: (i) at least 55% of all ADB committed sovereign and nonsovereign operations classified 
gender equity theme (GEN) and effective gender mainstreaming (EGM) by 2030;12 (ii) at least 75% 
of ADB’s committed sovereign and nonsovereign operations to promote gender equality through 
gender-inclusive project designs by 2030;13 and (iii) 80% of all ADB-financed projects and programs 
categorized GEN or EGM achieve gender equality success rating by 2030. There is also an 
increased focus on more transformative projects and programs that support the achievement of 
Sustainable Development Goal 5 (gender equality).  
 
10.  Limited gender data. In order to address key gender issues in the Pacific and to meet ADB 
gender equality corporate targets, further gender data and analysis is needed. There are limited 
systems and capacity in place to collect and monitor sex-disaggregated data. To date, data and 
analysis on the immediate impact of COVID-19 in Pacific DMCs has included limited information on 
the gendered impacts of COVID-19.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  gender  equality  outcomes  in  the  Pacific 
improved.14 The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome:  institutional  and  technical  capacity  for 
progressing gender equality outcomes strengthened.15  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  As well as mitigating the immediate risks of COVID-19 for women and girls, TA support is 
needed to ensure that gender equality gains are not lost and that women and girls are central to the 
socioeconomic recovery. The generation and sharing of knowledge and evidence, coupled with 
capacity development and stronger coordination, will help Pacific DMCs to strengthen their gender-
responsive policies and programs. While all Pacific DMCs are eligible for assistance under the TA 
upon request, the initial focus will be on COVID-19-related gender support in the Federated States 
of  Micronesia,  Fiji,  Palau,  Samoa,  Solomon  Islands  and  Vanuatu.16 Additional  requests  for 
assistance will be assessed and prioritized in accordance with the agreed outcomes and outputs 
below. If the approach of this TA is successful, additional financing may be considered to expand its 
activities to other DMCs. 
 
13.  Output 1: Gender-responsive policies and investments identified. The TA will provide 
technical expertise, assessments, and other analytical work to support at least three Pacific DMCs 
in  identifying  gender  mainstreaming  opportunities,  and  innovative  and  transformative  gender 
projects and programs. There will be particular focus on assessing the ongoing gendered impacts 
of COVID-19 and defining policies and investments to counter these. In addition, strategic technical

4 
 
inputs will be provided in the following areas: (i) proactive gender design features in policy-based 
lending; (ii) develop innovative gender designs that support the scope of Sustainable Development 
Goal 5; and (iii) enhance gender analysis and formulation of gender action plans in projects that are 
particularly strategic for demonstrating the importance of gender mainstreaming, or projects that 
could be categorized GEN. 
 
14.  Output 2: Capacity of Developing Member Countries to implement and monitor gender 
equality actions strengthened. The TA will help strengthen at least five DMCs’ capacity to 
implement, monitor, and report on gender equality activities and outcomes, including monitoring the 
gender  results  of  Pacific  operations  under  the  COVID-19  Pandemic  Response  Option.  TA 
consultants will also provide targeted capacity development to executing agencies, implementing 
agencies, and national gender machineries through in-country or online briefings, training, and other 
support, as requested. The TA team will support the production of case studies on good practices in 
gender  mainstreaming  and  the  achievement  of  gender  equality  results.  It  will  collect  sex-
disaggregated data and help Pacific DMCs to put in place stronger systems to collect such data.  
 
15.  Output 3: Gender partnerships strengthened and knowledge products produced and 
shared. The TA will create knowledge solutions and strengthen partnerships to improve gender 
equality outcomes in the Pacific. It will work with stakeholders (including SPC) and governments to 
develop a research agenda and a knowledge product dissemination plan that meet the needs of 
Pacific DMCs. A particular focus will be on GBV prevention and on developing gender knowledge 
products to inform the policies and plans for COVID-19 response and recovery. This output will 
support coordination and collaboration with the Pacific Partnership to develop and launch a Pacific 
regional GBV prevention hub and online portal.17 This will catalyze the investments made in GBV 
prevention to date, and build on existing partnerships in the Pacific to ensure sustainability. It will 
create a Pacific evidence base that highlights what works to prevent GBV, and fosters coordination 
and knowledge management among Pacific DMCs to ensure effective and evidence-based GBV 
prevention. To share knowledge and lessons, and to support learning and capacity development, 
the TA will also ensure that representatives of at least two Pacific DMCs participate in person or 
virtually in regional and/or global conferences, such as the United Nations Commission on the Status 
of Women and the triennial conference of Pacific Women and Pacific Women’s Ministers meeting.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.225 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6: $650,000; TASF-other sources: $575,000). The cost 
estimate and financing plan is in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented from August 2020 to July 2025. ADB, through its Pacific 
Department, will administer the TA, including selecting, supervising and evaluating consultants and 
procuring goods and non-consulting services. The Pacific Department will work closely with the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department’s Gender Equity Thematic Group to 
ensure  complementarity  with  other  gender  initiatives  in  ADB.  The  ministries  or  departments 
responsible for women’s affairs in participating DMCs will be the implementing agencies. The DMCs 
will designate a TA focal point and assistant to review reports and coordinate activities and in-kind 
contributions. The Pacific Department will maintain close coordination with field offices, other 
development partners, and regional organizations in the Pacific. Disbursement of TA proceeds will 
 
17 The online portal will be developed in accordance with para. 20 of the staff instructions. This TA will assist in developing 
and launching the knowledge portal, which will be hosted by a regional body or partnership such as the SPC or the 
Pacific Partnership. No funds will be transferred to SPC or the Pacific Partnership to host and maintain the portal.

5 
 
follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
 
18.  ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. The TA will require a minimum of 30 person-
months of international and 96 person-months of national consulting services. International and 
national individual consultants will be engaged to support the implementation of activities. Consulting 
firms or civil society organizations may also be engaged for activities. The precise nature of experts 
and inputs will be defined based on the needs identified in consultation with beneficiary DMCs. The 
Pacific  Department  will  consult  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial  Management 
Department when finalizing the nature and extent of consulting inputs and of consultants’ terms of 
reference. The TA scope is also expected to expand to cover additional activities and will be 
replenished from time to time as funds are required and identified, including those from cofinancing 
sources and ADB-administered trust funds. Accordingly, the nature and extent of consulting inputs 
may increase and consultant contracts may be extended with corresponding budget increases 
subject to their satisfactory performance and continued availability. The outline terms of reference 
for consultants are available from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the provision 
of  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1.225  million  on  a  grant  basis  for 
Strengthening Gender Outcomes in Pacific COVID-19 Response and Recovery, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

1.  Gender-responsive policies and investments identified  
1.1 Finalize TA activities, participating DMCs, and timelines; secure approval of participating DMCs and 
ADB  for  the  detailed  workplan,  schedule,  and  deliverables  of  the  individual  consultants  and/or 
consulting firms (Q3 2020–Q4 2020)

reviews, with the full participation and engagement of government staff (Q4 2020–Q2 2024) 
1.3 Finalize draft assessments and reports with ADB and participating governments (Q4 2020–Q4 2024) 
 
2.  Capacity of DMCs to implement and monitor gender equality actions strengthened  
2.1 Engage consultants and prepare workplans and specific output targets for capacity-building activities 
(Q3 2020–Q4 2021)
